bug.short_desc: Clicking below scroll bar thumb only scrolls 4 lines

long_desc.thetext:
Observed in the online demo in table and tree samples (e.g. http://demo.qooxdoo.org/current/demobrowser/#table~Table_Window_Editor.html): when you click below the thumb in a vertical scroll bar, the table or tree only scrolls by about four lines. This is less than expected: usually clicking below the thumb scrolls by one page at a time. This convention is followed by most UIs (native and web-based).
Observed in Firefox 3.6 (Linux) and Google Chrome (6.0.472.62)
Andreas, what do you think? Should we change the current behavior?

I would also expect a real pagination, i.e. moving to the entire previous/next page (minus approx. the first/last item on the current page to expose the pagination effect).
How is this implemented right now? I somehow remember this topic came up before? Unspecified browser, since I guess it's common behavior.
Sounds like we should check how other tables work e.g. in native frameworks or other web frameworks. If they implement such a behavior, we should move to that too.

ExtJS: uses browser scroll bars and scrolls a page at a time
Grid example: http://dev.sencha.com/deploy/dev/examples/grid/array-grid.html Tree example: http://dev.sencha.com/deploy/dev/examples/tree/two-trees.html
wxWidgets: the grid control uses native scroll bars, scrolls a page at a time (this can be seen in the wxPython demo)
GTK: trees and lists scroll slightly less than one page at a time (about two items overlap); not sure if GTK has a grid control. Example: the Gnome file manager (nautilus)
